en: The present temple, surrounded by modern buildings, is the only remnant of the 19th century to have been spared by the demolitions of the 1960's. In fact, 3 temples were built on the same site. Alès Municipal ArchivesThe present temple, surrounded by modern buildings, is the only remnant of the 19th century to have been spared by the demolitions of the 1960's. In fact, three temples were built on the same site, the first of which dates back to 1579. It was an imposing building built to accommodate 5 to 6,000 Reformed people. It had 3 entrance doors, 15 rectangular windows. Its facade located on the rue Peyrolerie had a square tower topped by a bell tower. In 1685, the Revocation of the Edict of Nantes ordered the demolition of all the temples. In 1707, the Penitents built a chapel on its site. After the period known as the "Desert" during which the Protestants went into hiding, the Edict of Tolerance came into effect which gradually restored the rights of non-Catholics. In 1792, the Consistory was able to buy back the Chapel of the Penitents, which had been sold as "national property" during the Revolution. But this chapel was in very bad condition, too small. After many ups and downs, the Presbyteral Council decided in 1854 to build a new temple, on the same site, enlarged by the building of the boys' school and two houses. The plans and specifications were drawn up by Mr. Léon Feuchères and then, on his death, by Mr. Revoil. The defense was supported by the Consistory and the City of Alès. The Temple stands out from other temples in the region by the use of the neo-Romanesque style. It was inaugurated on December 3, 1868 and in 1938 the 19th century organ was restored. In 1993, a new organ was installed. On December 16, 2000, two bells were installed in the bell tower; their names are "David" and "Marie Durand". In 2002, a 10-year plan was put in place to completely renovate the building and bring it up to standard (Sources: Alès Municipal Archives)
fr: Le temple actuel, entouré d'immeubles modernes, est le seul vestige du XIXe siècle à avoir été épargné par les démolitions des années 1960.A vrai dire, sur ce même emplacement, ont été bâtis 3 temples. Archives Municipales d’AlèsLe temple actuel, entouré d'immeubles modernes, est le seul vestige du XIXe siècle à avoir été épargné par les démolitions des années 1960.A vrai dire, sur ce même emplacement, ont été bâtis 3 temples.Le premier date de 1579. C'était un édifice imposant construit pour accueillir 5 à 6000 Réformés. Il comportait 3 portes d'entrée, 15 fenêtres rectangulaires. Sa façade située rue Peyrolerie comportait une tour carrée surmontée d' un clocher. En 1685, La Révocation de l'Edit de Nantes ordonne la démolition de tous les temples. En 1707, les Pénitents vont construire une chapelle sur son emplacement.Après la période dite du "Désert" durant laquelle les protestants vont se cacher, survient l'Edit de Tolérance qui va peu à peu rétablir les non-catholiques dans leurs droits. En 1792, le Consistoire peut racheter la chapelle des Pénitents vendue comme "bien national" à la Révolution. Mais cette chapelle est en très mauvais état, trop petite. Elle fait tout de même office de deuxième temple.Après bien des péripéties, le Conseil presbytéral décide en 1854 de construire un nouveau temple, sur le même emplacement, agrandi du bâtiment de l'école des garçons et deux maisons. Les plans et devis furent dressés par M. Léon Feuchères puis à son décès par M. Revoil. La défense fut supportée par le Consistoire et la Ville d'Alès. Le Temple se démarque des autres temples de la région par l'emploi du style néo-roman. Son inauguration eut lieu le 3 décembre 1868.En 1938, l'orgue du XIXe siècle est restauré. En 1993, un nouvel orgue est installé. Il est réalisé par Gérald Guillemin.Le 16 décembre 2000, le clocher reçoit deux cloches ; leur nom est « David » et « Marie Durand ». Une fontaine en pierre de taille vient embellir la place du temple.En 2002, un plan sur 10 ans est mis en place pour la rénovation complète du bâtiment et sa mise aux normes.(Sources : Archives Municipales d'Alès)

en:
The present temple, surrounded by modern buildings, is the only 19th-century vestige to have been spared the demolitions of the 1960s.

In fact, three temples were built on the same site

Municipal Archives of Alès

The current temple, surrounded by modern buildings, is the only vestige of the 19th century to have been spared by the demolitions of the 1960s.

In fact, on this same site, 3 temples have been built.

The first one dates back to 1579. It was an imposing building built to accommodate 5 to 6000 Reformed. It had 3 entrance doors, 15 rectangular windows. Its facade, located on Peyrolerie street, had a square tower topped by a bell tower

In 1685, the Revocation of the Edict of Nantes ordered the demolition of all temples. In 1707, the Penitents built a chapel on its site.

After the period known as the "Desert" during which the Protestants went into hiding, the Edict of Tolerance came into effect and gradually restored the rights of non-Catholics. In 1792, the Consistory was able to buy back the Penitents' chapel, which had been sold as "national property" during the Revolution. But this chapel is in very bad condition, too small. It was still used as a second temple.

After many ups and downs, the Presbyteral Council decided in 1854 to build a new temple on the same site, enlarged with the building of the boys' school and two houses. The plans and estimates were drawn up by Mr. Léon Feuchères and then, after his death, by Mr. Revoil. The defense was supported by the Consistory and the City of Alès. The Temple stands out from other temples in the region by the use of the neo-Romanesque style. Its inauguration took place on December 3, 1868.

In 1938, the 19th century organ was restored. In 1993, a new organ was installed. It was built by Gérald Guillemin.

On December 16, 2000, the bell tower receives two bells; their names are "David" and "Marie Durand". A stone fountain embellishes the temple square.

In 2002, a 10-year plan was put in place to completely renovate the building and bring it up to standard.

(Sources: Municipal Archives of Alès)
fr:
Le temple actuel, entouré d'immeubles modernes, est le seul vestige du XIXe siècle à avoir été épargné par les démolitions des années 1960.

A vrai dire, sur ce même emplacement, ont été bâtis 3 temples. 

Archives Municipales d’Alès

Le temple actuel, entouré d'immeubles modernes, est le seul vestige du XIXe siècle à avoir été épargné par les démolitions des années 1960.

A vrai dire, sur ce même emplacement, ont été bâtis 3 temples.

Le premier date de 1579. C'était un édifice imposant construit pour accueillir 5 à 6000 Réformés. Il comportait 3 portes d'entrée, 15 fenêtres rectangulaires. Sa façade située rue Peyrolerie comportait une tour carrée surmontée d' un clocher. 

En 1685, La Révocation de l'Edit de Nantes ordonne la démolition de tous les temples. En 1707, les Pénitents vont construire une chapelle sur son emplacement.

Après la période dite du "Désert" durant laquelle les protestants vont se cacher, survient l'Edit de Tolérance qui va peu à peu rétablir les non-catholiques dans leurs droits. En 1792, le Consistoire peut racheter la chapelle des Pénitents vendue comme "bien national" à la Révolution. Mais cette chapelle est en très mauvais état, trop petite. Elle fait tout de même office de deuxième temple.

Après bien des péripéties, le Conseil presbytéral décide en 1854 de construire un nouveau temple, sur le même emplacement, agrandi du bâtiment de l'école des garçons et deux maisons. Les plans et devis furent dressés par M. Léon Feuchères puis à son décès par M. Revoil. La défense fut supportée par le Consistoire et la Ville d'Alès. Le Temple se démarque des autres temples de la région par l'emploi du style néo-roman. Son inauguration eut lieu le 3 décembre 1868.

En 1938, l'orgue du XIXe siècle est restauré. En 1993, un nouvel orgue est installé. Il est réalisé par Gérald Guillemin.

Le 16 décembre 2000, le clocher reçoit deux cloches ; leur nom est « David » et « Marie Durand ». Une fontaine en pierre de taille vient embellir la place du temple.

En 2002, un plan sur 10 ans est mis en place pour la rénovation complète du bâtiment et sa mise aux normes.

(Sources : Archives Municipales d'Alès)

Alès Municipal ArchivesThe present temple, surrounded by modern buildings, is the only remnant of the 19th century to have been spared by the demolitions of the 1960's. In fact, three temples were built on the same site, the first of which dates back to 1579. It was an imposing building built to accommodate 5 to 6,000 Reformed people. It had 3 entrance doors, 15 rectangular windows. Its facade located on the rue Peyrolerie had a square tower topped by a bell tower. In 1685, the Revocation of the Edict of Nantes ordered the demolition of all the temples. In 1707, the Penitents built a chapel on its site. After the period known as the "Desert" during which the Protestants went into hiding, the Edict of Tolerance came into effect which gradually restored the rights of non-Catholics. In 1792, the Consistory was able to buy back the Chapel of the Penitents, which had been sold as "national property" during the Revolution. But this chapel was in very bad condition, too small. After many ups and downs, the Presbyteral Council decided in 1854 to build a new temple, on the same site, enlarged by the building of the boys' school and two houses. The plans and specifications were drawn up by Mr. Léon Feuchères and then, on his death, by Mr. Revoil. The defense was supported by the Consistory and the City of Alès. The Temple stands out from other temples in the region by the use of the neo-Romanesque style. It was inaugurated on December 3, 1868 and in 1938 the 19th century organ was restored. In 1993, a new organ was installed. On December 16, 2000, two bells were installed in the bell tower; their names are "David" and "Marie Durand". In 2002, a 10-year plan was put in place to completely renovate the building and bring it up to standard (Sources: Alès Municipal Archives)
